name: Alan Wake 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1224p to 4K PSSR/FSR. Mostly stable 30fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR/FSR at a locked 40fps. Combines the RT of the quality mode with image settings of performance. Requires 120hz display.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR/FSR. Mostly stable 60fps (lows of 50fps) with no RT. Graphics settings of base PS5 quality mode (more foliage/better lighting etc).

extraInfo: Can toggle between PSSR and FSR for upscaling. FSR is less noisy and more 4K like in stills. PSSR looks sharper in motion with less artifacting. Differences are less obvious in quality mode as base resolution is 1224p (others look relatively soft regardless as 864p to 4K is a big jump). There's no RT on base PS5 and Pro's quality mode also has higher quality shadows, volumetric lighting and fog. Both modes have a more stable framerate than their base PS5 counterparts.

name: Apex Legends

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Targets 4K at 60fps with high visual quality. In practice, the fidelity/quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Targets 1080p at 120fps with reduced visual quality.

extraInfo: These 2 modes are also on base PS5, but Pro hits the target framerate more often than their base PS5 counterparts. Interestingly, Apex Legends doesn't follow the standard naming convention as there's actually no fidelity/graphics mode.

name: Arken Age

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4096p per eye at 60fps re-projected.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 2240p per eye at 90fps native (no-reprojection).

extraInfo: Developers recommend the performance mode, likely due to the native motion. Base PS5 resolutions are 2432p in quality mode and 2048p in performance mode (framerates remain the same).

name: Arma Reforger

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1944p to 4K FSR 1 at a nearly locked 30fps. Has better ambient occlusion, enabled contact shadows, shadows on terrain surfaces, and improved cloud quality compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K FSR 1 at a relatively unstable 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 is exactly the same, but at 1620p and 1080p respectively. Performance mode has a decent amount of screen tearing. You can add an FPS counter to the HUD.

name: Asphalt Legends Unite

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at up to 120fps. Usually around 90fps with VRR during racing.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Up to native 4K at a locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Pro performance mode's resolution doesn't dip very far from 4K in order to maintain 120fps. Hard to tell the difference unless looking at each mode side-by-side.

name: Assassin's Creed Mirage
extraInfo: Through PSSR, Pro combines the 4K resolution, better shadows/reflections, higher texture resolution, and improved draw distance seen in the base PS5 30fps quality mode, with the 60fps seen in base PS5 performance mode. The framerate is also a nearly locked 60fps and more stable than base PS5 performance mode.

name: Assassin's Creed Shadows

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Usually around 1584p to 4K TAAU at a locked 30fps. Has both RT reflections and RTGI for diffuse lighting throughout the game world. Higher quality draw distances, foliage density, shadows, textures, hair quality etc than performance mode.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Usually around 1440p to 4K TAAU at a locked 40fps. Graphical settings straddle between quality and performance modes (no RT reflections but has RTGI, shadow resolution of performance mode, hair strands of quality mode etc).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Usually around 1080p to 4K TAAU at a very stable 60fps (lows of low 50s). No RT reflections, but RTGI remains throughout the world.

extraInfo: Cutscenes and the hideout run at 30fps in all modes. PSSR will be coming in a future patch that will allow balanced mode to also render RT reflections. RTGI is far more important to the image quality than RT reflections. Base PS5 performance mode only has RTGI in the hideout, making the Pro performance mode a generational leap in image quality due to the improved lighting. There's also no RT reflections on base PS5.

name: Astro Bot
extraInfo: 1872p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps. Despite Pro's DRS regularly having a lower base resolution than base PS5 (1872p vs 2160p etc), the Pro's PSSR upscaling is cleaner/sharper with less aliasing compared to the TAA on base PS5, but also noisier (especially SSR) and more unstable. The introduced noise isn't particularly visible at normal viewing distances however.

name: Atomfall
rtTypes: Ray-traced soft shadows (obscurance fields setting on PC)
extraInfo: Pro can render a full 4K at a locked 60fps, whereas base PS5 renders a maximum of 1800p. However, both have a low of 1440p and neither hit their top resolution most of the time. All versions are also poorly aliased (even PC), so resolution differences are less noticeable than in other games because there's so much shimmer/jaggies regardless. There's also low resolution surfaces and very poor SSR (equivalent to PC low settings) that exacerbate the shimmer. Finally, the overkill AO (including the RT) overly silhouettes the image (especially characters) and can't be turned off.

name: Avatar: Pandora Frontiers

modes.name: quality pro
modes.description: 900p - 1152p at mostly stable 60fps.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Sharper than quality pro (1512p - 1800p) but at locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Visual quality downgraded compared to quality but now at locked 40fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Lowest visual quality of all modes. Usually 936p at nearly locked 60fps compared to base PS5 at 720p/less stable 60fps.

extraInfo: All modes can use either PSSR or FSR3 for upscaling. FSR is less noisy and looks sharper in stills. PSSR is less stable but sharper and clearer in motion. PSSR works best with the quality 30fps mode. Quality/balanced/performance are all the legacy modes from base PS5, but will run at the higher resolution bounds (1800p for quality etc) more often due to the Pro's extra power.

name: Baldur's Gate 3

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at nearly locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a mostly stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Pro performance mode looks better than even base PS5 quality mode due to upscalers used. PSSR is a bit softer than base PS5's FSR, but much more stable with less artifacting/flicker. This is especially seen in motion like moving shadows. Pro also has around a 10% higher framerate, so runs at 60fps more often than base PS5. Split screen can now run at either 30fps or 60fps.

name: Black Myth: Wukong

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1296p to 4K PSSR at a very stable 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1296p to 4K PSSR at a very stable 40fps on 120hz screens or 45fps on 60hz. Lower resolution shadows than quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p to 1440p FSR3. Frame-gen used to target a still unstable 60ps.

extraInfo: Unlike most Pro games, PSSR isn't much noisier than FSR and offers the clearest image. Base PS5 performance mode is very similar to the Pro and also uses frame generation. However due to frame gen, the quality/balanced modes have less input lag and therefore feel more responsive despite fewer frames. Base PS5 balanced and quality modes only target an upscaled 1440p and use non-frame gen FSR as its upscaler.

name: Biped
extraInfo: Biped has no display options, so things like an 120fps mode are not available. However, Pro at least maintains a locked 60fps. Pro renders a 1440p image compared to base PS5's more 1080p-like image. The difference can be quite noticeable on things like railings where there's more jaggies on base PS5.

name: Biped 2
extraInfo: Biped 2 isn't out yet, but the following Biped 1 information should give us at least a good base of what to expect. Biped has no display options, so things like an 120fps mode are not available. However, Pro at least maintains a locked 60fps. Pro renders a 1440p image compared to base PS5's more 1080p-like image. The difference can be quite noticeable on things like railings where there's more jaggies on base PS5.

name: Call Of Duty: Black Ops 6

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a mostly locked 60fps, or typically around 70-90fps with VRR. Improved global illumination (biggest improvement), ambient occlusion, reflections and 2-4x shadow resolution compared to performance mode.

modes.name: 120 hz refresh rate
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at relatively stable 120fps. Graphics settings the same as base PS5 fidelity mode that runs at 60fps.

extraInfo: The anti-lag VRR implementation in fidelity mode (120hz refresh rate toggle off) means it actually has lower input latency than the 120hz mode, despite fewer frames. An improved PSSR implementation also arrived in a patch that significantly reduced artifacting/white dots in some areas, although they're still somewhat visible on rare occasions. Splitscreen multiplayer is now a locked 60fps (mid 50s on base PS5).

name: Days Gone Remastered
extraInfo: There will be both a performance and quality mode for base PS5. There will be increased foliage draw distance, improved shadow and lighting quality compared to the PS4 version. We will see how those improvements compare between base PS5 and Pro closer to release.

name: Dead Island 2
extraInfo: Pro has improved shadow quality, motion blur, texture filtering and depth of field compared to base PS5. There's also longer draw distances and contact shadows on all objects/lights. The framerate is a locked 60fps like base PS5. Pro's resolution is above 2000p for the majority of gameplay, including often at native 4K. It can drop down as low as 1620p (technically lower than base PS5's fixed 1728p), but this is very rare only last a couple of seconds.

name: Dead Rising Deluxe
extraInfo: Base PS5 doesn't have any RT implementation. Reflections are a big improvement with RT due to the shopping mall setting (storefront windows etc). You can toggle RT off, but Pro has a locked 60fps regardless. Whereas base PS5 dips into the low 50s in the most demanding scenarios. Both base PS5 and Pro run at a native 4K however.

name: Demon's Souls

modes.name: PS5 pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584p to 4K PSSR with improved shadows at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: cinematic
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 4K native at locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 1440p at locked 60fps.

extraInfo: While the native 4K in base PS5's cinematic (quality) mode is a little sharper than the Pro mode, it's also far more noisy, more aliased, and less temporally stable than the 1440p-1584p to 4K PSSR in the Pro mode, which therefore has the better image quality despite the lower base resolution. The Pro mode also has improved shadows and a locked 60fps.

name: Diablo IV

modes.name: enhanced visuals
modes.description: Up to 4K native at 30fps. RT shadows and reflections. Improves quality of fur, hair and fog compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 60fps. No RT.

extraInfo: Enhanced visuals mode hovers around 45-50fps with VRR, so VRR isn't recommended as that's below the 48fps VRR threshold on PlayStation. Pro's enhanced visuals mode also has higher resolutions, improved ambient occlusion and higher quality RT reflections compared to the same mode on base PS5.

name: Dragon Age: The Veilguard

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Roughly 1296p to 4K PSSR at nearly locked 30fps with RTAO.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Roughly 864p-1296p to 1800p PSSR at nearly locked 60fps with RTAO. Can flicker a lot/look very aliased due to low base resolution.

extraInfo: Base PS5 uses FSR instead of PSSR. Is 1080p to 1800p FSR and 864p to 1440p FSR respectively. Base PS5 is a lot softer, but less flickering/aliasing can make foliage/reflections etc look better compared to Pro. You can see the differences in the background of the menu when toggling between the modes (AO on foliage etc).

name: Dragon's Dogma 2

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at an unevenly paced 30fps. Around 40-50fps with VRR.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR at relatively locked 60fps (lows of low 50s).

modes.name: prioritize performance
modes.description: 720p to 4K PSSR at mostly locked 60fps. Usually around 70-85fps with VRR.

extraInfo: All modes can toggle RTGI on/off and the framerate is around 10 fewer with it activated. Due to PSSR, RT is noisy/aliased and looks worse as the base resolution lowers in subsequent modes. This exacerbation is also true with regular occlusion, although PSSR creates a sharper image and significantly improves ghosting, texture detail and material quality. Pro also hits its target framerate much more often than base PS5.

name: Dying Light 2: Stay Human
rtTypes: Ray-traced shadows, reflections and ambient occlusion.

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: Native 4K at 30 FPS. Better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 30 FPS with RT. Now with increased base resolution (1440p) and better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 60 FPS. Increased base resolution (1512p) compared to base PS5.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K with VRR, up to 120 FPS. Increased base resolution (1440p), better contact shadows, spot shadows, and fog quality compared to base PS5.

extraInfo: All modes also have improved Global Illumination, Screen Space Reflections (except quality mode due to RT) and Sub Surface Scattering compared to their equivalent base PS5 mode.

name: Dying Light: The Beast
rtTypes: Ray-traced shadows, reflections and ambient occlusion.

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: Native 4K at 30 FPS. Better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 30 FPS with RT. Now with increased base resolution (1440p) and better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 60 FPS. Increased base resolution (1512p) compared to base PS5.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K with VRR, up to 120 FPS. Increased base resolution (1440p), better contact shadows, spot shadows, and fog quality compared to base PS5.

extraInfo: No hard technical figures just yet, but Techland have publicly come out and said DL: The Beast will take it much further than DL2: SH. So we should expect what's above at the very least depending on the mode.

name: Dynasty Warriors: Origins

modes.name: native 4K
modes.description: 4K at a very unstable 60fps.

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1512p-4K at a nearly locked 60fps.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1440p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Prioritize graphics mode averages around 1700p during actual gameplay and the framerate can dip into high 50s. Native 4K mode barely hits 60fps and is usually around 50fps during combat.

name: EA College Football 25
rtTypes: GIBS (EA's own global illumination - hardware ray tracing for indirect lighting)
extraInfo: Removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. PSSR renders a sharper screen than even base PS5 resolution mode, but it causes certain assets like crowd handrails to be more unstable. All cutscenes are now also 60fps like in base PS5 performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps. Finally, RT implementation seems unchanged.

name: EA Sports FC 25
extraInfo: Combines the resolution and enhanced visuals modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. Pro sometimes renders an even sharper image than base PS5 resolution mode, but still has the enhanced visuals mode RTAO on pitch lighting/kits etc. Cutscenes are now also 60fps, as opposed to 30fps on base PS5.

name: EA Sports UFC 5
extraInfo: Pro's resolution during gameplay is slightly higher than base PS5. Pro also renders KO replays at 60fps instead base PS5's 30fps. Other cutscenes like ring entrances remain at 30fps.

name: Empire Of The Ants
extraInfo: Base PS5 can have a higher internal resolution as it ranges from 1400p-1600p to 4K TSR, but it only runs at 30fps. Pro's base resolution of 1440p is also high enough that  there is barely a difference between the consoles once UE5's TSR upscaling is implemented.

name: Enlisted

modes.name: high quality
modes.description: 4K at a basically locked 60fps.

modes.name: high performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at a stable 120fps.

extraInfo: High performance mode now hits a solid 120fps whereas the base PS5 version is usually around 90fps. There's also higher quality shadows, improved Global Illumination and due to PSSR, the overall image quality has improved.

name: F1 24
rtTypes: Ray-traced dynamic diffuse global illumination, ambient occlusion, shadows and reflections

modes.name: 8K
modes.description: 4K to 8K TAAU at a locked 30fps. Gameplay has all RT, including shadows. Requires an 8K TV as it can't be down-sampled.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1440p to 4K PSSR. Locked 60fps with all RT in gameplay except shadows.

modes.name: 120 Hz performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p to 4K TAAU. Mostly at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Base PS5 quality mode has no RT during gameplay, whereas Pro has 3/4 RT which dramatically improves image realism. Pro even brings back shadows for cutscenes (which are now at 40fps, instead of 30fps) and replays. Base PS5 quality mode resolution is 1800p-4K, yet PSSR very nearly matches its sharpness despite a much lower base DRS. Base 120 Hz performance mode is also usually at 1080p compared to Pro's 1440p.

name: Faaast Penguin
extraInfo: The only display setting in the options menu is a brightness slider. However, Pro has a locked framerate and runs within an 120hz container to improve input lag (base PS5 still at 60hz). Pro could potentially sometimes render below 4K native, but these dips would be so minor that the game still has a 4K-like image.

name: Farming Simulator 25
extraInfo: Whereas base PS5 has a quality (1600p to 4K at 30fps) and performance 60fps mode, Pro just has a singular mode that runs at a native 4K at a basically locked 60fps.

name: Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth

modes.name: versatility
modes.description: 1224p-1440p to 4K PSSR at a very stable 60fps.

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 1880p-4K native at locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 performance mode(s), with a sharp or smooth variation. 1152p-1440p at a stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Pro's new versatility mode runs at 1224p-1440p to 4K PSSR at a very stable 60fps. All base PS5 modes are present and its 30fps graphics mode can have a higher internal resolution. However the PSSR implementation, though a bit noisier/unstable, still creates a far sharper image (especially distant detail), with better SSR and less ghosting/artifacting, at 60fps. Considering versatility mode has both the clearest resolution and highest/most stable framerate (its 60fps is more stable than the performance mode), all other modes are redundant.

name: Fortnite
rtTypes: Hardware-based RT reflections, shadows & global illumination

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1350p to 4K TSR at near locked 60fps with hardware-based RT reflections, shadows & global illumination.

modes.name: 120fps performance
modes.description: 1080p to 4K TSR at basically locked 120fps, but with no RT.

extraInfo: 120fps performance mode looks practically identical to base PS5. Fidelity mode on base PS5 uses software-based RT, meaning Pro has better RT implementation due to being hardware-based (less breakup/shimmering/pop-in, more detailed/stable assets, character models in reflections, more accurate indirect lighting etc).

name: Forza Horizon 5

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K (likely) at 30fps with RT reflections in races/free roam.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Higher fidelity graphics 60fps.

extraInfo: The above information comes directly from the Forza support page. So although accurate, the details will be more extensive once the game has released and we have the opportunity to test out the modes ourselves.

name: God Of War: Ragnar√∂k
rtTypes: Very light RT reflections for scene-aligned cube maps.

modes.name: PS5 pro enhanced
modes.description: Quality settings of base PS5 (RT, better shadows/ambient occlusion/textures & longer draw distance than HFR) but runs at 4K/60+fps instead of 30fps.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: Unlocks framerate for up to 120fps (often around 70-105fps depending on upscaler) on VRR displays.

modes.name: Favor Quality
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 quality mode capped at 30fps.

modes.name: Favor Performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 quality mode capped at 60fps.

extraInfo: Can toggle between TAA and PSSR for upscaling. PSSR is sharper and clearer (especially distant assets) with less fizzle in motion, but less stable with around 10-20 frames fewer. Both upscalers use 1440p as the base resolution. No need to bother with the legacy base PS5 modes as there are no advantages to do so.

name: Gran Turismo 7

modes.name: 8K 60hz
modes.description: 4K to 8K PSSR at locked 60fps, but with no RT. Requires PSSR to upscale.

modes.name: prioritize ray-tracing/resolution
modes.description: 4K PSSR/TAA at locked 60fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1800p to 4K PSSR/TAA at locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Unlike base PS5, RT reflections are now available during gameplay. Its excellent implementation is far superior to the cube maps used when RT is disabled. Both TAA and PSSR are available for upscaling. RT is available with both except for cockpit mode, which is only PSSR. PSSR still looks great, but can can produce additional shimmer/noise in thin objects and artifacting on a few cars compared to TAA. All framerates are locked 99% of the time in gameplay, but replays can drop the framerate more often. Finally, Pro significantly improves motion clarity and image quality inside PSVR2.

name: Helldivers 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at an improperly paced, but stable 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p at a mostly stable 60fps (drops to 50s with explosions etc).

extraInfo: Resolution increases in both modes as on base PS5, quality mode is 1728p and performance is 1080p. However, all 4 modes' images are relatively unstable due to mediocre TAA. Resulting in a larger gap between performance modes than quality modes (less shimmering/clearer text etc). 60fps on Pro is also more stable than on base PS5, with only the hardest difficulties causing drops (usually still in the VRR window). Both quality modes remain improperly paced, but the Pro version is more stable.

name: Hitman Trilogy
extraInfo: A locked 60fps at 4K, compared to the 1800p mostly stable 60fps on base PS5. Essentially, putting it on par with the Series X version.

name: Hogwarts Legacy

modes.name: fidelity ray-tracing
modes.description: 1728p to 4K PSSR at nearly locked 30fps with RT reflections and shadows.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1728p to 4K PSSR at locked 30fps without RT.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Only for 120hz screens. 4K PSSR at nearly locked 40fps without RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at nearly locked 60fps without RT.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: Only for 120hz/VRR screens. Can drop to 1080p as base resolution and no framerate cap. Usually around 80fps.

extraInfo: You can remove the framerate cap in the fidelity and balanced modes, increasing the framerate by 5-10. RT shadows are better quality than base PS5, but less accurate on some moving objects. RT reflections have twice the resolution on Pro compared to base PS5. It also applies to bodies of water unlike base PS5 which uses SSR, though can look noisy due to PSSR. Pro performance modes have same graphical settings as the other Pro modes outside of RT. Base PS5 uses FSR 1 to upscale, which looks sharper, but more aliased than PSSR.

name: Horizon 1 Zero Dawn

modes.name: favor resolution pro
modes.description: Up to 4K native at locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced pro
modes.description: Looks almost identical to favor performance pro mode, but is capped at 40fps.

modes.name: favor performance pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584 to 4K at locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Very slightly more blurry than favor resolution pro mode (particularly SSR) due to lower base resolution before upscaling, but looks less aliased in motion.

extraInfo: All 3 modes have improved shadows, depth-of-field, skin/hair shaders, clouds, god rays etc compared to base PS5, and these improvements are even more noticeable in motion. Base PS5 hits max 1800p checkerboarding in performance mode which looks far blurrier (especially foliage and SSR in bodies of water) and more aliased/unstable than Pro performance mode. Pro performance even beats base PS5 resolution mode except for slightly blurrier SSR. Digital Foundry thinks it's the best looking console game (along with Horizon 2) ever! Equivalent to a high-end PC game and even beats DLSS in places like SSR.

name: Horizon 2 Forbidden West

modes.name: favor resolution pro
modes.description: Up to 4K native at locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced pro
modes.description: Looks almost identical to favor performance pro mode, but is capped at 40fps.

modes.name: favor performance pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584 to 4K at locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Very slightly more blurry than favor resolution pro mode (particularly SSR) due to lower base resolution before upscaling, but looks less aliased in motion.

extraInfo: All 3 modes have improved shadows, depth-of-field, skin/hair shaders, clouds, god rays etc compared to base PS5, and these improvements are even more noticeable in motion. Base PS5 hits max 1800p checkerboarding in performance mode which looks far blurrier (especially foliage and SSR in bodies of water) and more aliased/unstable than Pro performance mode. Pro performance even beats base PS5 resolution mode except for slightly blurrier SSR. Digital Foundry thinks it's the best looking console game (along with Horizon 1) ever! Equivalent to a high-end PC game and even beats DLSS in places like SSR.

name: Hunt: Showdown 1896
extraInfo: According to Crytek, Pro has 'increased graphical settings' compared to base PS5 and Pro's 60fps is more stable. PSSR also creates a sharper image than the 1260p to 4K FSR2 on base PS5. However, the PSSR implementation (which you can't toggle off) results in a lot more shimmering/flickering than FSR2. To the point that many feel the image actually looks worse despite the sharper render. There's also anecdotal comments throughout the community that Pro suffers from crashes more often.

name: Kayak VR: Mirage
extraInfo: Has 8K textures compared to 4K on base PS5. Also improves post-processing, effects, LOD distance and anti-aliasing. Dynamic resolution only hits a low of 90% of 4K, whereas base PS5 can only render between 60-90% of 4K.

name: Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2
extraInfo: Pro is 1296p-1440p to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps, or around 70fps (highs of 90s) with VRR enabled. Base PS5 is only 1080p to 1440p FSR when targeting 60fps, though 1440p to 4K FSR at 30fps. However, even with Pro sometimes using a lower base resolution before upscaling, PSSR still produces the clearest (albeit a little noisier) image. Pro also has the same improved tree/shadow LODs, ambient occlusion and object quality of base PS5's fidelity mode, making the Pro mode the best of both worlds.

name: Lies Of P

modes.name: quality-centered
modes.description: 4K at 40fps+ depending on if HFR (VRR) is activated. Higher quality shadows, textures, SSR and volumetric fog than performance-centered mode.

modes.name: performance-centered
modes.description: 4K at a basically locked 60fps. HFR is disabled in this mode.

extraInfo: Pro performance mode is a native 4K, whereas the same mode on base PS5 renders at 1512p-1800p internally before being upscaled to 4K. Pro quality mode also has a 30% increase in FPS compared to base PS5 quality mode.

name: Like A Dragon: Pirate Yakuza In Hawaii
pageTitle: Like A Dragon: Pirate Yakuza In Hawaii
extraInfo: The framerate is a basically locked 60fps. There is noticeably less fizzle in things like hair compared to the base PS5 version.

name: Lords Of The Fallen

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps with Lumen GI.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K via a custom version of UE5's upscaling at 60fps plus Lumen.

extraInfo: Hexworks state a 40% increase in pixel density compared to the base PS5 modes, resulting in sharper distant details and more refined textures on characters and environments. In practice, this increase could be even larger as base PS5 performance mode was between 648p-1152p and quality mode was 1296p-1620p. Pro also hits its target framerate more often than base PS5 and is equivalent to the highest graphical settings on PC.

name: Madden NFL 25
extraInfo: Removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. PSSR renders a sharper screen than even base PS5 resolution mode (especially grass), but it causes certain assets like crowd handrails to be more noisy/unstable. All cutscenes are now also 60fps like in base PS5 performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps.

name: Marvel Rivals
rtTypes: UE5 Lumen Global Illumination & Lumen Reflections

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, with Lumen Reflections & GI.

modes.name: HFR
modes.description: 1440p at a nearly locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 only has Lumen GI in its quality mode, whereas Pro also has Lumen Reflections. Pro's PSSR implementation renders a sharper image than possible on base PS5, but is also a bit noisier/unstable. Pro also not only hits 120fps in its HFR mode much more often than base PS5, which regularly dips to around 110fps, but does so at a higher resolution too.

name: Metal Gear Solid Delta: SE
extraInfo: Konami have confirmed that there will be both a quality and performance mode on Pro. They also confirmed that Pro will use PSSR, but didn't mention if it's just for performance mode or for both. Based off the PC requirements, it's likely that the Pro will also have some form of RT (traditional or UE5-specific Lumen) but this has yet to be confirmed.

name: Monster Hunter Wilds

modes.name: prioritize resolution
modes.description: 1728p-1944p to 4K PSSR with RT reflections. Nearly locked 30fps, or up to 45fps with VRR.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1404p to 4K PSSR with very slightly worse RT. Nearly locked 40fps, or low 40s in VRR.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR with RT disabled. Nearly locked 60fps, or up to 80fps with VRR. Worse GI, lighting and LODs than other modes.

extraInfo: RT reflections look significantly better than SSR due to no occlusion issues. Pro's PSSR looks much better than base PS5's FSR1 as the image (though slightly softer) has a lot less aliasing/breakup and more temporal stability. This contrast is widened as the base resolution lowers to as low as 720p on base PS5. Pro prioritize framerate mode also hits 60fps more often than base PS5. LFC doesn't trigger in prioritize resolution/balanced modes, so VRR isn't recommended.

name: Mortal Kombat 1
extraInfo: Only big difference between the PS5 Pro and base PS5 versions is that the Pro version uses ray-tracing for reflections. The pro version still has DRS that can go as low as 1800p, but hits 4K more often than base PS5.

name: Naraka: Bladepoint

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at 60fps. According to 24 Entertainment - 'ideal for users seeking better visual experiences'.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1080p (likely) to 4K PSSR, with either a 60fps or 120fps cap - 'balancing both visual quality and smoothness'.

modes.name: high frames
modes.description: Native 1080p at 60fps, 120fps, 240fps, or 'unlimited' fps (check extra info) - 'for users who need the highest frame rates, ensuring smoother gameplay'.

extraInfo: According to the developers, 60fps at a native 4K wasn't possible on base PS5. The max framerate section has toggles for both a 240fps cap or unlimited fps, but the PS5 Pro is not capable of going above 120fps. So in reality, it has the same 60/120fps cap toggles as balanced mode.

name: NBA 2K25
extraInfo: The biggest difference between Pro and base PS5 is the addition of RT reflections in The City. Pro also uses PSSR to upscale from 1440p (likely) to 4K. This creates a slightly sharper image compared to base PS5, however PSSR also causes certain assets like handrails in the stands to render a bit more unstable.

name: Ninja Gaiden 2 Black
rtTypes: Software-based UE5 Lumen reflections and GI

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Upscaled 4K TSR at locked 60fps except for some cutscenes (lows of mid 50s).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 1080p TSR at somewhat stable 120fps depending on level (lows of 90s). Less detailed shadows/non-Nanite geometry.

extraInfo: Neither modes are officially named - instead, you switch between the 2 via the FPS limit toggle that has 60 and 120 values. Both modes use Lumen combined with SSR for reflections and Lumen GI for indirect lighting. Both modes are the same as the two on base PS5. However, the Pro has a higher base resolution before upscaling and hits its target framerate more often.

name: No Man's Sky

modes.name: 8K resolution
modes.description: 2592-2700p to 8K PSSR at locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a basically locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Both modes also have improved lighting, ultra quality reflections and higher quality ambient occlusion compared to base PS5. These improvements are also seen in the PSVR2 version. PSSR implementation works very well due to the high base resolution.

name: Off The Grid

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K FSR3/TSR/PSSR at usually around 65fps with VRR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p FSR3/TSR/PSSR at usually around 85fps with VRR.

extraInfo: Pro can choose between FSR3, TSR or PSSR for upscaling. All 3 run at a similar fps (give or take 5-10fps) and can be capped at 30/40/60fps. However, while FSR3 and TSR (a bit more stable) render a good image, PSSR results in shimmering/flickering, as well as strobing in assets like foliage. Similar to horror stories from games like SW Jedi: Survivor when Pro launched, before getting patched. Fidelity mode renders quite a 4K-looking image and is 99% locked above the 48fps VRR window. Performance mode has a roughly 20fps increase and even hits 120fps sometimes, but the 1080p-like image is much blurrier regardless of upscaler.

name: Outbreak: SOHCS
pageTitle: Outbreak: Shades of Horror Chromatic Split
extraInfo: Uses PSSR to hit 4K (base resolution unknown, but almost certainly above 1080p due to final output). Pro also has significantly enhanced RT, texture resolution, other visual effects etc compared to base PS5, and hits 60fps more often.

name: Pathfinder: WOTR

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a relatively stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Quality mode can dip below 60fps, but it's not common. Even when it happens, it's around the low 50's which is well within the VRR window. Performance mode is a locked 60fps, but at 1/4 of the resolution. Base PS5 only has one mode which is 4K, but with a far more unstable framerate that is regularly below the VRR window.

name: Ratchet & Clank: Rift Apart

modes.name: fidelity pro
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps/40fps for 60hz/120hz screens, or nearly 60fps with VRR. Highest quality RT (explained below).

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1584p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 80-90fps with VRR.

extraInfo: Fidelity Pro is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, but PSSR in general resolves more detail than FSR on base PS5. Especially in motion with less aliasing etc, but can be noisier in stills. Performance Pro mode has much sharper RT reflections than base PS5 Performance RT mode. Fidelity Pro RT reflections looked even less aliased as they are full resolution and its RTAO has more contact shadows, adding depth to assets all over the screen.

name: Redacted

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a locked 120fps with supersampling.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 8K at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 doesn't have an 8K mode. It also can't run at 120fps when rendering at 4K. You can choose quality mode on a non-8K screen, but the game makes it clear that the game will be down-sampled to the resolution of your screen and therefore make this choice pointless.

name: Resident Evil 4

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: 4K at locked 60 with RT/Hair. Can also toggle HFR on which then increases the framerate to 70-90fps.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR without RT/Hair. 85-105fps usually, but can be a locked 120fps in interiors.

extraInfo: There's a lot of toggles in this game for RT/HFR/better hair quality etc, so the 2 modes above represent the image quality with all the toggles either on or off. Resolution mode holds a much more stable 60fps than base PS5, which hovered around 45fps.

name: Resident Evil Village
rtTypes: Ray-traced global illumination, ambient occlusion & reflections

modes.name: ray tracing
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps with RT.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: You can actually toggle both RT and HFR on, with the framerate generally ranging from from 65-90fps. 120fps is not available on base PS5, which uses 4K checkerboarding (1920x2160) and also can't hold a stable 60fps. PSSR is less sharp compared to base PS5 checkerboarding, but also less noisy, with less artifacting on moving objects like tree branches.

name: Retrieval
extraInfo: The Pro version will have more detailed environments, higher quality RT reflections and a sharper resolution compared to the base PS5 version. All at a more stable 60fps.

name: Rise Of The Ronin

modes.name: prioritize graphics + ray tracing
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR with RT reflections. Same framerate issues as other graphics mode.

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a very unstable 60fps cap. Averages around 45fps in actual gameplay.

modes.name: prioritize FPS
modes.description: 1070p-1440p to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Both graphics modes' framerate falls far below the VRR limit for the majority of gameplay. There is a toggle to cap the framerate to 30fps, but it has uneven frame pacing so these modes will feel choppy regardless of your screen setup. The superior RT reflections make little difference in this scenario because of the framerate issue. However, even with the lower resolution in prioritize fps mode, Pro's PSSR is a lot less aliased/more clear than base PS5's FSR (even in its graphics modes). Especially in the foliage which regularly fills the screen.

name: Rogue Flight

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K at a very stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a very stable 120fps.

extraInfo: According to Truant Pixel, outside of the resolution and framerate increases in each mode compared to the same modes on base PS5, Pro also has 'additional small graphical touches'.

name: Shredders
extraInfo: Base PS5 and Pro both achieve a nearly locked 60fps. However, Pro runs at 4K native compared to base PS5's 1440p, which is a 2x resolution increase.

name: Silent Hill 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps with RT

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 900p-1152p to 4K TSR. Relatively locked 60fps (lows of high 40s) with RT.

extraInfo: Pro uses superior hardware-based RT compared to software-based RT on base PS5 (less breakup/clearer reflections etc) and both modes hit target framerate more often than the base PS5 version. Pro performance mode also has a higher base resolution. Pro quality mode, despite a more 4K like image and better RT, has so much PSSR shimmer that base PS5 quality mode looks better due to TSR. Bloober should either improve PSSR implementation or revert to TSR (as they did for performance).

name: Slitterhead
extraInfo: A native 4K and more stable 60fps compared to base PS5, especially in later boss fights. *Technical information is aggregated off anecdotal remarks by gamers who have completed Slitterhead, not from a primary source or established secondary source like Digital Foundry as none exist at time of writing.

name: Smash Drums
extraInfo: Developers have confirmed 120fps native on the Pro and that there will be other enhancements.

name: Sniper Elite: Resistance
extraInfo: Pro hits native 4K often, which is extremely rare on base PS5. Base PS5 also renders a low of 1296p much of the time when that's less than 1% on Pro. However, all versions (Xbox/PC too) are poorly aliased, so resolution differences are less noticeable than in other games because there's so much shimmer regardless. 60fps is locked outside of some explosions. This is more stable than base PS5 which drop frames in general play.

name: Spider-Man 1 Remastered

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 fidelity mode (all RT/ more asset density etc). 4K at locked 30fps/40fps for 60hz/120hz screens.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or usually around 75-90fps with VRR. Fidelity mode level of image quality (RT/increased pedestrian density etc).

extraInfo: Performance Pro (which is the mode Insomniac recommend) also now has RT unlike base PS5 performance mode. Fidelity is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, especially in areas like reflections, but PSSR in general still resolves more detail than seen on base PS5.

name: Spider-Man: Miles Morales

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 fidelity mode (all RT/ more asset density etc). 4K at locked 30fps/40fps for 60hz/120hz screens.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or usually around 75-90fps with VRR. Fidelity mode level of image quality (RT/increased pedestrian density etc).

extraInfo: Performance Pro (which is the mode Insomniac recommend) also now has RT unlike base PS5 performance mode. Fidelity is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, especially in areas like reflections, but PSSR in general still resolves more detail than seen on base PS5.

name: Spider-Man 2

modes.name: fidelity pro
modes.description: 4K PSSR at locked 30fps/40fps for 60hz/120hz screens, or usually around mid 50s with VRR. Highest quality RT (explained below).

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or usually around 70fps with VRR. Base PS5 level of RT quality.

extraInfo: Fidelity Pro is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, but PSSR in general resolves more detail than the upscaler on base PS5. Fidelity Pro RT key light shadows now includes very distant buildings, RT reflections are full resolution as opposed to 50% in Performance Pro, and RTAO has more contact shadows, adding depth to assets all over the screen. RT types can be toggled on/off which affects VRR framerate around +- 10. Draw distance/distant reflections are also improved over Performance Pro (which is at base PS5 Fidelity level), e.g. more onscreen distant objects like trees. Graphics settings in general equivalent to high/very high on PC.

name: Split Fiction
extraInfo: The framerate is a locked 60fps. Base PS5 renders at 1800p compared to 4K native on Pro. However due to the current aliasing implementation Pro (and PC) use, certain assets like railings can look more jagged despite the higher resolution. This is likely a bug that will be an easy fix in a future patch. Despite being on Unreal Engine 5, the Pro (and again, even on PC) doesn't use RT.

name: Star Wars Jedi: Survivor
rtTypes: Ray-traced reflections, Global Illumination & Ambient Occlusion

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1584p to 4K PSSR. Locked 30fps with more detailed RT implementation compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 900p average to 1800p PSSR. Nearly locked at 60fps with RT.

extraInfo: Pro now has the latest PSSR version, which is far less noisy/unstable/shimmery than the original, objectively ugly patch. Flickering in foliage and RT reflections are especially improved and is now on par with FSR on base PS5. PSSR is also sharper than FSR (and even DLSS on PC) in motion, though softest in stills. Pro performance mode also brings back RT that's not in the base PS5 version, but the implementation is still worse than either PS5's quality mode.

name: Star Wars Outlaws

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 900p - 1152p at a nearly locked 60fps.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Sharper than quality pro (1512p - 1800p) but at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Visual quality downgraded compared to quality but now at a locked 40fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Lowest visual quality of all modes. Usually 936p at a nearly locked 60fps compared to base PS5 at 720p.

extraInfo: All modes can use either PSSR or FSR3 for upscaling. FSR looks clearer/less noisy with assets like foliage in stills, but the difference is small now that Outlaws updated its PSSR implementation, which beats FSR in motion. Quality mode is the only one that provides stable RT.  Quality/balanced/performance are all the legacy modes from base PS5, but will run at the higher resolution bounds (1800p for quality etc) more often due to the Pro's extra power.

name: Stellar Blade

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1800p to 4K PSSR. A very nearly locked 80fps on 120hz screens and 60fps on 60hz screens.

modes.name: pro max
modes.description: 4K TAA at 50-60fps.

modes.name: prioritize resolution
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 quality mode. See below for reasons why it's redundant.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 balanced mode. See below for reasons why it's redundant.

modes.name: prioritize performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 performance mode. See below for reasons why it's redundant.

extraInfo: The legacy modes from base PS5 are still present, but like Pro Max mode, they use TAA. The 80fps Pro mode is the only one that uses PSSR. The PSSR implementation is far better than TAA at de-noising/sharpening/stabilizing/de-shimmering the image. So even with a lower base resolution (1800p), Pro mode looks better than the native 4K TAA in Pro Max, let alone the legacy modes that max out at 60fps. With the best image quality and highest framerate, Pro mode makes all the others redundant.

name: Stunt Paradise
extraInfo: While both the base PS5 and Pro versions run at 120fps, base PS5 is limited to 1440p. PS5 Pro runs at 4K.

name: Subside
extraInfo: Both base PS5 and the Pro run at 90fps with no reprojection. However, the Pro version has dynamic shadows and the edge blur effect. It also has a 2.5x foveated resolution increase compared to the 2.25x increase on base PS5. The developers believe the dynamic shadows produce the largest improvement between the versions.

name: Test Drive Unlimited: SC

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at 30fps

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p at a nearly locked 60fps

extraInfo: Base PS5 graphics mode only renders at 1440p, but there is little difference in practice. Pro is also able to achieve its target framerate more often.

name: The Callisto Protocol

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 6K to 8K TAAU at locked 30fps with RT. Can be down-sampled back to 4K for a clearer image on 4K screens.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 4K TAAU at a very stable 40fps with RT. Higher internal resolution than performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1296p - 1440p to 4K TAAU at a nearly locked 60fps with RT.

extraInfo: Performance mode has the biggest jump from base PS5 as that performance mode has no RT and a more unstable 60fps. RT quality is the same on Pro and base PS5, so there isn't much difference in the quality modes outside of resolution.

name: The Crew Motorfest
extraInfo: Looks much more detailed than even base PS5's 30fps resolution mode due to more objects, decals, vegetation and crowds. However, there is no introduction of RT. The 60fps is also locked at 1700p (approx) to 4K PSSR, which is a big improvement over base PS5's 1080p in performance and even its 30fps mode which renders at 1440p.

name: The Finals
extraInfo: The only difference between the Pro and base PS5 is a resolution increase. General gameplay looks slightly sharper on Pro with a more stable 60fps due to the extra GPU horsepower. The RTGI quality remains the same and there is no option for 120fps.

name: The First Berserker: K

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1440p (likely) to 4K at a relatively stable 60fps. At least when it matters most (see extra info).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Around 1220p (approx) to 4K at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Quality mode holds a 60fps for the majority of combat. It can dip when lots of graphical effects are onscreen, but still stays above the 48fps VRR window. However, it can fall below that threshold in cutscenes. You can remove the framerate limit, but the game recommends that you keep it at 60fps or below.

name: The First Descendant
rtTypes: Ray-traced shadows, reflections on translucent and opaque surfaces, ambient occlusion, and radiance cache.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K PSSR at 30fps, or up to 60fps with frame generation on. Has all RT if turned on.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Same as fidelity mode, but aims for 40fps via a lower internal resolution before upscaling to 4K PSSR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p PSSR at 60fps, which is achieved more often with frame gen on. Has all RT except for RT shadows and translucent surface reflections.

extraInfo: One of the few Pro games to combine PSSR with AMD's FSR frame generation, whereas base PS5 uses FSR for upscaling. You can toggle both RT and frame generation on/off in all modes. Frame generation increases framerates, but isn't recommended as the base framerate is too low, resulting in too much input lag.

name: The Last Of Us Part I

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 70-90fps with VRR.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps, 40fps with a 120Hz display, or 50-60fps with VRR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at a locked 60fps, or around 80-110fps with VRR.

extraInfo: The fidelity and performance modes are the same as on base PS5. The PSSR in Pro mode looks much sharper (especially foliage) than performance mode's TAA. There's also less noise/anti-aliasing in motion and improved SSR compared to both, but fidelity mode is still very close in image quality and some reflections can even look better. For VRR, there is usually around a 25fps advantage in comparison to the same mode being run on base PS5. PSSR beats the FSR implementation in the PC version and comes very close to DLSS.

name: The Last Of Us Part II

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 70-90fps with VRR.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps, 40fps with a 120Hz display, or 50-60fps with VRR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at a locked 60fps, or around 80-110fps with VRR.

extraInfo: The fidelity and performance modes are the same as on base PS5. The PSSR in Pro mode looks much sharper (especially foliage) than performance mode's TAA. There's also less noise/anti-aliasing in motion and improved SSR compared to both, but fidelity mode is still very close in image quality and some reflections can even look better. For VRR, there is usually around a 25fps advantage in comparison to the same mode being run on base PS5. PSSR beats the FSR implementation in the PC version and comes very close to DLSS.

name: TopSpin 2K25
extraInfo: Pro now runs cutscenes/replays at 60fps instead of the 30fps on base PS5. This is the only upgrade as there's no resolution/gameplay differences between Pro and base PS5 (4K/60fps on both).

name: Truck Driver: TAD
rtTypes: Ray-traced reflections, ambient occlusion and global illumination.

modes.name: fidelity pro 30fps
modes.description: Prioritizes resolution over framerate. Dynamic 4K PSSR at locked 30fps. Has improved shadows, lighting and draw distance compared to performance modes. Also has RTAO/GI/reflections.

modes.name: fidelity pro unlocked
modes.description: Prioritizes framerate over resolution. Dynamic 4K PSSR at 60/120fps. Has improved shadows, lighting and draw distance compared to performance modes. Also has RTAO/GI/reflections.

modes.name: performance RT pro
modes.description: Favors higher framerates (40/60/120fps) over resolution, which is 1080p-1440p, but with

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Favors higher framerates (40/60/120fps) over resolution, which is 1080p-1440p. No RT.

extraInfo: PSSR implementation produces much better assets, including moving ones like foliage, compared to TSR on base PS5. The resolution is also higher and there's better shadows regardless of mode. Pro also uses hardware accelerated RT reflections, RTAO and RTGI compared to the inferior software based RT on base PS5. Finally, the performance RT mode is exclusive to PS5 Pro.

name: UFL
extraInfo: Pro runs at a locked 60fps and native 4K. The display options are very similar to what you seen in FIFA/EA FC games. Therefore, there's no options for things like a 120fps mode.

name: Until Dawn

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K at a stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Until Dawn allows you to render at 2.39:1 ratio for a more cinematic look with black bars but a wider viewing angle, or the usual 16:9. This doesn't affect resolution or framerate. Base PS5 also has a fidelity and performance mode that targets the same framerate but at lower resolutions.

name: War Thunder
extraInfo: Pro can render up to 4K native, whereas base PS5 only runs at 1080p when aiming for 120fps.According to Gaijin, Pro also gets 'more improvements and additional optimization'. However, there's still a good amount of shimmer on assets like railings despite the up to 4x increase in resolution.

name: Warframe
extraInfo: There's no strict quality/performance modes, nor can you go above 60fps. Instead, Warframe's menus are very PC-like in UI. For example, you can toggle graphical settings of aspects like particle quality and volumetric fog. You can also toggle PSSR on/off. If on and all graphical settings so to their highest, the framerate is a basically locked 60fps. If toggled off/no upscaler used, it will rarely maintain 60fps, but will stay above the 48fps VRR window for the vast majority of gameplay.

name: Warhammer 40,000: DT
extraInfo: Base PS5 renders either performance mode 1440p/60fps (936p internal) or quality mode 4K/30fps (1440p internal). Pro renders at 4K/60fps (1270p internal) and looks sharper (especially in motion) than even base PS5 quality mode, despite the lower internal resolution, due to PSSR. The framerate on Pro is also more stable in areas where base PS5 isn't, but can become unstable at higher difficulty levels due to more enemies onscreen. The Pro version also runs most graphical settings equivalent to 'high' on PC.

name: Warhammer 40,000: RT

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: 4K at a nearly locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p at 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 doesn't have a graphics mode equivalent as it can't run the game at a native 4K, so there is only one mode. Pro also has a much more stable framerate in both of its modes compared to base PS5.

name: Warhammer 40K SM2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-2160p to 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps

modes.name: speed
modes.description: 1080p-1440p to 4K PSSR at a relatively stable 60fps. Drops to around 50fps in more chaotic scenes.

extraInfo: Base PS5 uses FSR2 to upscale its modes, and both have a lower base resolution before upscaling (e.g. 720p for speed mode). The result is a noticeably blurrier image compared to the Pro versions, especially in motion where PSSR excels. Pro also hits 60fps more often, though it's still not ideal as it can fall out of the VRR window.

name: Wolverine
rtTypes: Ray-traced reflections, shadows & ambient occlusion (based off Spider-Man 2)

modes.name: fidelity pro
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps/40fps for 60hz/120hz screens, or mid 50s with VRR. Highest quality RT (based off Spider-Man 2).

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 70fps with VRR. Base PS5 level of RT quality (based off Spider-Man 2).

extraInfo: Please note the above technical information is subject to change as Wolverine is still in development. However, this information is from leaked internal Insomniac documents and/or what Insomniac did with Spider-Man 2, so I decided it was worth including in the detailed games list to get a baseline of expectations.

name: World Of Warships: L
extraInfo: Pro runs at 4K/60fps which interestingly, is the same as the Series X version. Base PS5 only runs at 1440p/60fps, which means a 50% increase in resolution for Pro. There's also an RT toggle for hardware-based reflections, but the framerate is then capped at a locked 30fps.

name: Zenless Zone Zero
extraInfo: The game runs at a native 4K and relatively stable 60fps. At times when it dips under, it's still around 10 frames higher than the base PS5 version. The Pro version also introduces ray-traced reflections, ambient occlusion, and improved diffuse lighting. You can toggle off RT for a much more locked 60fps.

name: Zombie Derby
extraInfo: While both the base PS5 and Pro versions run at 120fps, base PS5 is limited to 1440p. Pro runs at 4K, which is 2x the resolution and with a nearly locked framerate.

name: Zombie Derby 2
extraInfo: While both the base PS5 and Pro versions run at 120fps, base PS5 is limited to 1440p. Pro runs at 4K, which is 2x the resolution and with a nearly locked framerate.

name: Zombie Derby: PS
extraInfo: While both the base PS5 and Pro versions run at 120fps, base PS5 is limited to 1440p. Pro runs at 4K, which is 2x the resolution and with a nearly locked framerate.
